name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
19. Two books on the nature of the public intellectuals who lead our society:
Intellectuals by Paul Johnson
Intellectuals and Society by Thomas Sowell

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
18. Three books on the philosophical underpinnings of our time:
The End of History and the Last Man by Francis Fukuyama
Alexandre Kojève: Wisdom at the End of History by James Nichols
Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: 17. History Has Begun: The Birth of a New America by Bruno Macaes -- on the country and culture the United States is evolving into, not necessarily decline, but something very different.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: 16. Public Choice Theory and the Illusion of Grand Strategy by Richard Hanania -- a sobering reexamination of how democratic governments actually make decisions.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
15. Two of Thomas Sowell's many brilliant books on how our current politics and culture came to be:
A Conflict of Visions: Ideological Origins of Political Struggles
The Vision of the Anointed: Self-Congratulation as a Basis for Social Policy

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
14. Two more books on who we are and how we got here, one on culture, the other on genetics:
The WEIRDest People In The World by Joseph Henrich
Who We Are And How We Got Here by David Reich

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
13. Two books on the evolution of modern culture and civic religion, both by John Murray Cuddihy:
No Offense: Civil Religion and Protestant Taste
Ordeal of Civility

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: 12. The Power of the Powerless by Vaclav Havel -- the definitive work on practical life under totalitarianism.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: 11. The Captive Mind by Czeslaw Milosz -- the definitive work on intellectual life under totalitarianism.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: 10. The True Believer by Eric Hoffer -- a brilliant book on the nature of mass movements and collective psychology.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: 9. Two books on fascism and anti-fascism, titled Fascism and Anti-Fascism respectively, both by Paul Gottfried.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: 8. A New World Begins by Jeremy Popkin, on the French Revolution.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
7. A comprehensive biography and a key chronicle of Vladimir Lenin.
Lenin by Victor Sebestyen
Lenin On The Train by Catherine Merridale

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
6. Six books on the deep history of the American left.
The God That Failed by Richard Crossman
The Romance of American Communism by Vivian Gornick
Witness by Whittaker Chambers
Joseph McCarthy by Arthur Herman
Days of Rage by Bryan Burrough
Radical Chic by Tom Wolfe

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
5. Two comprehensive biographies of Adolf Hitler.
Hitler: A Global Biography by Brendan Simms
Hitler: Ascent and Hitler: Downfall by Volker Ullrich

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
4. Six books on the deep history of the American right.
Lindbergh by Scott Berg
The Ambassador by Susan Ronald
The Guarded Gate by Daniel Okrent
The Second Coming of the KKK by Linda Gordon
War For Eternity by Benjamin Teitelbaum
The New Right by Michael Malice

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
3. Four books on the Spanish Civil War, which was the trial run for the hundred years of Western history that followed.
The Spanish Civil War by Hugh Thomas 
Homage to Catalonia by George Orwell
Spain In Our Hearts by Adam Hochschild
Mine Were Of Trouble by Peter Kemp

name: Marc Andreessen

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: Mainly I try to learn a lot. For example, the political events of 2014-2016 made clear to me that I didn't understand politics at all, so I deliberately withdrew from political engagement and fundraising.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: I am currently on 12 boards, 9 private and 3 public, and try to always have at least one slot open for the next big thing.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: I spend much of the rest of my time helping to evaluate and close new investments. Most new investments A16Z makes are not led by me, but I often partner with my colleagues to land new deals, and I occasionally lead an investment with a founding team I particularly connect with.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: I am stunned daily by the creativity and courage of our founders, and I love working with all of them.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: I work extensively with our many portfolio companies and their teams -- some where I'm on the board, but many where I'm not but can scrub in at key times, usually either when things are going really right or really wrong.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: We are about to pass 500 employees, we've dramatically expanded our investing scope, and we've implemented an entirely new operating model on the other side of COVID. I could not be more proud of the firm and our colleagues, and we're just getting started.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: We are in my 14th year of working to build our venture firm, Andreessen Horowitz. The overwhelming credit for A16Z's accomplishments goes to Ben and all our partners, but I do what I can to contribute.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Professional-Managerial Class" by Barbara and John Ehrenreich, 1977, https://t.co/SGnaVLzpk0 (of course Brown! 🙂)

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The inner life of the PMC must be continuously shaped, updated, and revised by--of course--ever mounting numbers of experts in childraising, family living, sexual fulfillment, self-realization, etc. etc."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "As a result of the anxiety about PMC class reproduction, all of the ordinary experiences of life--growing up, giving birth, childraising--are freighted with an external significance unknown in other classes."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The children of PMC members do overwhelmingly tend to marry within the class; marriage down to the working class or up to the [prior] ruling class is comparatively infrequent. Children of PMC families are more than 2x more likely to themselves enter PMC professions."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "All characteristics of the PMC professions are aimed at ensuring that the relationship between the individual PMC professional and his or her 'client' (student, patient) is one of benign domination."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The possession (or claim to possession) of specialized knowledge ensures the PMC can control its own reproduction as a class: Lengthy training has barred working-class entrance to the PMC professions and given a decided advantage to the children of the PMC itself."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "In fact, American socialism was frequently not far from the PMC's vision. Socialism meant government ownership of the means of production (which would be administered by PMC experts) and expansion of social services (which would be supplied by PMC professionals)."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Although the early-20th-century US Socialist Party had a large working-class membership, most of the top leadership and a vastly disproportionate part of the membership were engaged in Professional-Managerial occuptions."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Progress demanded at the capitalists be swept away to make room -- not for the working class -- but for the rising class of experts."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Every effort to mediate class conflict and 'rationalize' capitalism served to create new institutional roles for reformers -- i.e. to expand the Professional-Managerial Class."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "'Social defense a matter for the expert. The rearing of dikes against faithlessness and fraud calls for intelligent social engineering. If the public does not speedily become far shrewder, there is nothing for it but to turn over the defense of society to professionals.'"

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The subjective dimension of contacts between the Professional-Managerial Class and the working class is a complex mixture of hostility and deference on the part of working class people, contempt and paternalism on the part of the PMC."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Professional-Managerial Class exists only by virtue of the expropriation of the skills and culture once indigenous to the working class."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "We define the Professional-Managerial Class as consisting of salaried mental workers who do not own the means of production." [But nevertheless control them through their managerial roles, per Burnham.]

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Professional-Managerial Class cannot be considered a stratum of a broader class of workers, because it exists in an objectively antagonistic relationship to another class of wage earners simply called the working class."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: It's shocking how prescient the original Professional-Managerial Class essay is. Since it was written in 1977, the PMC has eaten up most of the power and most of the money in our society while feeling rebellious and aggrieved the entire time. https://t.co/SGnaVLzpk0

tweet: “We are all capable of believing things which we know to be untrue, and then, when we are finally proved wrong, impudently twisting the facts so as to show that we were right. Sooner or later a false belief bumps up against solid reality, usually on a battlefield.”

tweet: “When some particularly absurd belief is exploded by events, one may simply forget that one ever held it.”

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "James Burnham had proposed the existence of a similar class in his 1941 book, The Managerial Revolution, arguing that they had become the new ruling class."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Hans Magnus Enzensberger had also observed the 'characterless opportunism' of its members, in reference to its constant shifting of allegiances, not only between the leisured and working classes but also among themselves."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Catherine Liu, in Virtue Hoarders (2021), characterized the PMC as white-collar left liberals afflicted with a superiority complex in relation to ordinary members of the working class."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The term was coined in 1977 by John and Barbara Ehrenreich. The term became widely used in American political discourse in the late 2010s as a shorthand to refer to technocratic liberals or wealthy Democratic voters."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: ""The professional–managerial class tends to have incomes above the average for their country, with major exceptions being academia and print journalism." [Who are compensated with power instead.]

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "This group of professionals is distinguished from other social classes by their training and education, typically business qualifications and university degrees, with occupations thought to offer influence on society that would otherwise be available only to capital owners."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The term professional–managerial class (PMC) refers to a social class within capitalism that, by controlling production processes through occupying a superior management position, is neither proletarian nor bourgeois."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Theodore Draper argued that 'the so-called theory of social fascism and the practice based on it constituted one of the chief factors contributing to the victory of German fascism in January 1933'." Oops.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The atmosphere of revolutionary fervour saw any enemy of the ruling group around Stalin denounced as 'wreckers' and 'traitors', an attitude that was translated on to the international stage, where both social democrats and communist dissidents were denounced as fascists."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Comintern's theory had roots in Grigory Zinoviev's argument that international social democracy is a wing of fascism. That view was accepted by Stalin, who described fascism and social democracy as 'twin brothers'."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "At the 6th World Congress of the Comintern in 1928, the beginning of the 'Third Period' was proclaimed. The end of capitalism, accompanied with a working class revolution, was expected and social democracy was identified as the main enemy of the communists."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The social fascism theory was advocated vociferously by the Communist Party of Germany, which was largely controlled and funded by the Soviet leadership from 1928."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The term social fascist was used pejoratively to describe social democratic parties, anti-Comintern and progressive socialist parties and dissenters within Comintern affiliates throughout the interwar period."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "At the time, leaders of the Comintern such as Joseph Stalin argued that capitalist society had entered the period in which a communist revolution was imminent, but this could be prevented by social democrats and other 'fascist' forces."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Social fascism was a theory that was supported by the Communist International (Comintern) and affiliated communist parties in the early 1930s that held that social democracy was a variant of fascism because it stood in the way of communism."

tweet: Frederick Douglass was pro both freedom of speech *and* "freedom of reach".

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: --Frederick Douglass, December 9, 1860 https://t.co/GsUqNKFefi

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "A man’s right to speak does not depend upon where he was born or upon his color. The simple quality of manhood is the solid basis of the right – and there let it rest forever."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Equally clear is the right to hear. To suppress free speech is a double wrong. It violates the rights of the hearer as well as those of the speaker. It is just as criminal to rob a man of his right to speak and hear as it would be to rob him of his money."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "There can be no right of speech where any man, however lifted up, or however humble, however young, or however old, is overawed by force, and compelled to suppress his honest sentiments."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Why, what is the matter with us? Are we going to palliate and excuse a palpable and flagrant outrage on the right of speech, by implying that only a particular description of persons should exercise that right?"

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Thrones, dominions, principalities, and powers, founded in injustice and wrong, are sure to tremble, if men are allowed to reason of righteousness, temperance, and of a judgment to come in their presence."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Liberty is meaningless where the right to utter one’s thoughts and opinions has ceased to exist. That, of all rights, is the dread of tyrants. It is the right which they first of all strike down. They know its power."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "No right was deemed by the fathers of the Government more sacred than the right of speech. It was in their eyes, as in the eyes of all thoughtful men, the great moral renovator of society and government."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: I welcome correction from Constitutional scholars, but also reserve my right as a citizen to have and express views that extend beyond jurisprudence. This is a civilizational question with the highest possible stakes.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: And here again, I think the starting point for consideration should be, what does the 231 year evolution of the legal *and* cultural doctrine of free speech in America tell us about the questions, the considerations, the tradeoffs, the very real risks.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: Maybe the government should also bind companies to either guarantee free speech, or conversely, to restrict and suppress and ban various kinds of speech. Opinions on this vary. I suspect we are going to something, and it will stand for a very long time.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: The First Amendment also theoretically guarantees freedom of association, yet our current legal regime sharply restricts freedom of association of many companies and other organizations, and we now consider those restrictions settled and not open for reconsideration.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: Third, it is also the case that many current and former government officials are presently demanding *legal* changes that would impose new requirements to either permit or ban various kinds of speech, *on companies*. This is not an abstract discussion; these demands are live.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: And it is within that context that I find it so striking that, while First Amendment case law includes a significant number of abridgements of absolute free speech, it contains no abridgments of so-called "misinformation" or "hate speech". I don't think this is accidental.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: And so, when considering demands for sweeping changes our societal conception of free speech, I think it is prudent and wise to reflect on the 231 year evolution of the legal doctrine of free speech, rather than dismissing all of that encoded wisdom as outdated and irrelevant.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: So while the *laws* of free speech are carefully specified by our legal system, the *principles* of free speech have been, and in the minds of many, continue to be important beyond legal specifics, and in fact central to the core functioning of our society.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: Because, second, free speech in our society is more than legalism, but an integral component of our way of life, our culture, our civilization. Hard fought, argued, and won by our ancestors over centuries. Incarnated *in* the Constitution, but not limited *to* the Constitution.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: First, it is certainly true, as the Professor indicates, that the First Amendment and associated case law binds the government ("Congress shall make no law...") and not companies or individuals. But, the topic does not end there.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: Excellent question! Professor Nyhan has forgotten more about these topics than I will ever know, but I will do my best as an amateur and citizen to respond.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: Somewhere between 2 and 10 Twitters.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The government cannot say for sure how much of the more than $900B in pandemic-related unemployment relief has been stolen, but estimates range from $87B to $400B — at least half of which went to foreign criminals, law enforcement officials say." https://t.co/qVqIRK4QQU

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: But it is striking how 231 years of American jurisprudence and case law have failed to incorporate sweeping bans on "misinformation" and "hate speech" that our moral superiors suddenly assure us are absolutely necessary for the functioning of our democracy.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Free speech absolutism" is a myth, nobody argues for that. And neither the First Amendment nor the Supreme Court support it. There are always carveouts from free speech, and presumably there always will be.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: However, there are no legally recognized concepts of "misinformation" or "hate speech". Both are recent constructs with no historical basis in American law, culture, or history.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: There are several additional categories of speech that are not protected under the first amendment. https://t.co/mZJDOoPv33

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The exception for child pornography is distinct from the obscenity exception in a few ways. First, the rule is much more specific to what falls under the exception. Second, if it is classified under the child pornography exception at all, it becomes unprotected."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Supreme Court has held that advocacy of the use of force is unprotected when it is directed to inciting or producing imminent lawless action and is likely to incite or produce such action."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Categories of speech that may be restricted include obscenity, fraud, child pornography, speech integral to illegal conduct, speech that incites imminent lawless action, speech that violates intellectual property law, true threats, and commercial speech such as advertising."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "In the United States, some categories of speech are not protected by the First Amendment. According to the Supreme Court of the United States, the U.S. Constitution protects free speech while allowing limitations on certain categories of speech."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: Yes.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: From James Burnham and Gaetano Mosca in https://t.co/DX0SxHaOYM

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "If a vote is to have any efficacy at all, each voter is forced to limit his choice to a very narrow field, to a choice among the two or three persons who have some chance of succeeding--those who are championed by groups, by committees, by organized minorities."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "In elections, as in all other manifestations of social life, those who have the will and, especially, the moral, intellectual and material means to force their will upon others take the lead over the others and command them."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "When we say the voters choose their representative, we are using inexact language. The truth is the representative has himself elected by the voters, and, if that phrase should seem too inflexible and too harsh to fit some cases, we might say that his friends have him elected."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "What happens in other forms of government—namely, that an organized minority imposes its will on the disorganized majority—happens also and to perfection, whatever the appearances to the contrary, under the representative system."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "It follows that the larger the political community, the smaller will the proportion of the governing minority to the governed majority be, and the more difficult will it be for the majority to organize for reaction against the minority."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The minority is organized for the very reason that it is a minority. A hundred men acting uniformly in concert, with a common understanding, will triumph over a thousand [or million, or billion] men who are not in accord and can therefore be dealt with one by one."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The dominion of an organized minority, obeying a single impulse, over the unorganized majority is inevitable. The power of any minority is irresistible as against each single individual in the majority, who stands alone before the totality of the organized minority."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "If it is easy to understand that a single individual cannot command a group without finding within the group a minority to support him, it is rather difficult to grant, as a constant and natural fact, that minorities rule majorities, rather than majorities minorities."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "...whether the society is feudal or capitalist or slave or collectivist, monarchical or oligarchical or democratic, no matter what the constitutions and laws, no matter what the professions and beliefs."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The existence of a minority ruling class is, it must be stressed, a universal feature of all organized societies of which we have any record. It holds no matter what the social and political forms..."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "In practical life we all recognize the existence of this ruling class. We all know that, in our own country, the management of public affairs is in the hands of a minority of influential persons, to which management, willingly or unwillingly, the majority defer."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "...in a manner that is now more or less legal, now more or less arbitrary and violent, and supplies the first, in appearance at least, with material means of subsistence and with the instrumentalities that are essential to the vitality of the political organism."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The first class, always the less numerous, performs all political functions, monopolizes power and enjoys the advantages that power brings, whereas the second, the more numerous class, is directed and controlled by the first..."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "In all societies—from societies that are very meagerly developed and have barely attained the dawnings of civilization, down to the most advanced and powerful societies—two classes of people appear—a class that rules and a class that is ruled."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: This is how so many of these speech disputes go. The main question is not truth or falsehood or etc., it's whether a topic is useful for establishing the political friend/enemy distinction. Once it's not, the topic is fine to discuss, as it has become nonpolitical.

tweet: Every modern manufacturing operation also requires machines that themselves require parts, maintenance, and ongoing support to operate. More and more of these machines will have a cloud tether that will be required to keep them running, and will enable remote shutdown.

tweet: Every year, more manufactured things contain chip and software components that simply can’t be switched out without completely redesigning the product. Most manufacturing operations are completely incapable of building these components themselves.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Star Chamber could inflict any punishment short of death, and frequently sentenced objects of its wrath to the pillory, to whipping and to the cutting off of ears. With each embarrassment to arbitrary power the Star Chamber became emboldened to undertake further usurpation."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Star Chamber became notorious for judgments favourable to the king, for example when Archbishop Laud had William Prynne branded on both cheeks through its agency in 1637 for seditious libel."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "King James I and his son Charles used the Star Chamber to examine cases of sedition, which meant that the court could be used to suppress opposition to royal policies."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Star Chamber became a political weapon for bringing actions against those who opposed the policies of King Henry VIII, his ministers and his parliament."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "However, this meant that the justice meted out by the Star Chamber could be very arbitrary and subjective, and it enabled the court to be used later on in its history as an instrument of oppression rather than for the purpose of justice for which it was intended."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "This gave the Star Chamber great flexibility, as it could punish defendants for any action which the court felt should be unlawful, even when in fact it was technically lawful."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Another function of the Star Chamber was to act like a court of equity, which could impose punishment for actions which were deemed to be morally reprehensible but were not in violation of the letter of the law."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "In modern times, legal or administrative bodies with strict, arbitrary rulings, no due process rights to those accused, and secretive proceedings are sometimes called 'star chambers' as a metaphor."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "However, the Star Chamber became synonymous with social and political oppression through the arbitrary use and abuse of the power it wielded."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Star Chamber was originally established to ensure the fair enforcement of laws against socially and politically prominent people so powerful that ordinary courts might hesitate to convict them of their crimes."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "At least part of this puzzle is resolved here by the finding that only 20 basis points of the rate of return to capital was due to Schumpeterian profits [that flow to innovators vs the rest of society]."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "How could the rate of profit be so low, it might be asked, given that the denominator omits several important assets (such as land and intangible investments) and the numerator includes important sources of profits (such as monopoly power and Schumpeterian profits)?"

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Over the last four decades [prior to 2004] in which we have careful measurement, the rate of profit after tax on nonfinancial corporations averaged 5.9%, which was very close to the cost of capital over that period."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "In terms of the rate of profit on capital, the rate of profit on the replacement cost of capital over the 1948-2001 period is estimated to be 0.19% per year."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "American capitalism grinds Schumpeterian profits--the profits from innovation that go to innovators--into such a fine powder that they can barely be detected in the macroeconomic realm."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "It is well established that innovators do not generally capture the entire social value of inventive and innovational activity."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Innovations produce social value as well as private value. When copy machines replace scribes, or computers replace hand calculations, the social cost of producing a given amount of goods and services declines."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Only a miniscule fraction--about 2.2%--of the social returns from technological advances over the 1948-2001 period was captured by producers, indicating that most of the benefits of technological change are passed on to consumers rather than captured by producers.""

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Once the barbarians solidify their control over the conquered society, however, they become attracted to its more refined aspects. Then, eventually, the former barbarians will be conquered by a new set of barbarians, who will repeat the process."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Civilizations have lifespans like individuals, and that every state will eventually fall because sedentary luxuries distract them, and eventually government begins to overtax citizens and begin injustice against property rights, and 'injustice ruins civilization'."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Its inevitable weakening, due to a complex combination of psychological, sociological, economic, and political factors, heralds the decline of a dynasty or empire and prepares the way for a new one, based on a group bound by a stronger cohesive force."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Asabiyya, which arises spontaneously in tribes and other small kinship groups, but which can be intensified and enlarged by a religious ideology, provides the motive force that carries ruling groups to power."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Their asabiyya dissolves into factionalism and individualism, diminishing their capacity as a political unit. Conditions are thus created wherein a new dynasty can emerge at the periphery of their control, grow strong, and effect a change in leadership, continuing the cycle."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "As they establish themselves at the center of their empire, they become increasingly lax, less coordinated, disciplined and watchful, and more concerned with maintaining their new power and lifestyle."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The new rulers are at first considered 'barbarians' in comparison to the previous ones."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Ibn Khaldun argued that a civilization has within itself the seeds of its own downfall."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Asabiyyah is strongest in the nomadic phase, and decreases as civilization advances. As this declines, another more compelling asabiyyah may take its place; thus, civilizations rise and fall, and history describes these cycles as they play out."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Ibn Khaldun describes asabiyya as the bond of cohesion among humans in a group-forming community. The bond exists at any level of civilization, from nomadic society to states and empires."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Asabiyya is cyclical and related to the rise and fall of civilizations: it is strongest at the start of a civilization, declines as the civilization advances, and then another more compelling asabiyyah eventually takes its place to help establish a different civilization."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The concept was familiar in the pre-Islamic era, but became popularized in Ibn Khaldun's Muqaddimah, in which it is described as the fundamental bond of human society and the basic motive force of history."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Asabiyya is neither necessarily nomadic nor based on blood relations. In the modern period, it is generally analogous to solidarity, nationalism, or partisanship."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Asabiyyah or asabiyya (Arabic: عصبيّة) is a concept of social solidarity with an emphasis on unity, group consciousness, and a sense of shared purpose and social cohesion, originally used in the context of tribalism and clanism."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
https://t.co/pgQVJhJ7z2

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "And, on top of it, Schmitt also says that such a view that we don’t have Enemies is a flawed view of human nature.  Man lusts for domination.  Man lusts for power.  Man lusts for control."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Even if everyone managed to become Friends, Schmitt implies that we would make someone an Enemy just because that is human nature and that is what politics is about."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "And since man is political, and this is part of his human nature, those who attempt to eliminate conflict and transform enemies into 'rational actors' whom one can persuade to not have qualms with, are nihilists out to destroy man’s political nature."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "To have no power to decide who to include as a member of the body and who to exclude as a member of the body, is to not be political at all."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Enemy, which leads to conflict, is essential to the nature of the world and meaning in life.  Without the Enemy, life would be meaningless and shallow."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "[But today,] the Enemy is principally the force that threatens what humans have achieved [in the political realm]."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "At the very beginning of human existence there has always been something, or someone, that threatened existence.  That was the Enemy."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "This is a consequence of pluralism – that is, real difference.  If we’re not all the same (monism) then there must be difference and differentiation by definition."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Following Hegel, one only knows oneself through the Other.  The Other is almost always going to be an enemy as the Other stands apart from you and your community (the Other may be an ally but is always potentially an enemy)."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Herein lies Schmitt’s essential Hegelianism: the friend-enemy (those who are part of your community and those who are not part of your community) is foundational to understanding oneself."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The drawing of a Friend-Enemy distinction, therefore, is never a mere reaction to a threat to a form of existence that is already given. Rather, it actively constitutes the political identity or existence of the people and determines who belongs to the people."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "A political community exists, then, wherever a group of people are willing to engage in political life by distinguishing themselves from outsiders through the drawing of a Friend-Enemy distinction."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "A group that perceives its own existence to be threatened by some other group finds itself in an analogous position. The possibility of third-party mediation is therefore ruled out in a truly political conflict."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The decision whether someone else’s behaviour constitutes a threat to one’s own life, in some concrete situation, and the decision whether it is necessary to use reactive or even pre-emptive violence to remove or to escape that threat, cannot be delegated to a third person."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Since the political community is the social unit that can dispose of people’s lives, it will be able, where it exists, to assert its superiority over all other social groups within its confines and to rule out violent conflict among its members."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "But wherever a distinction has political quality, it will be the decisive distinction and the community constituted by it will be the decisive social unit."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Political identification is likely to latch on to another distinction that will inherit the lethal intensity of political conflict."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Since the political is not tied to any particular substantive distinction, it is naïve to assume that the political will disappear once conflicts arising from a particular distinction no longer motivate opposing groups to fight."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Whether a particular distinction will come to play this role is not determined by its own intrinsic significance but by whether a group of people relies on it to define its own collective identity."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Any distinction that can serve as a marker of collective identity and difference will acquire political quality if it has the power, in a concrete situation, to sort people into two opposing groups that are willing, if necessary, to fight against each other."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The political distinction between Friend and Enemy is not reducible to any particular distinction — be it linguistic, ethnic, cultural, religious, etc. — that may become a marker of collective identity and difference."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Political enmity can have many different origins. The political differs from other spheres of value in that it is not based on a substantive distinction of its own."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The utmost degree of association is the willingness to fight and die for and together with other members of one’s group, and the ultimate degree of dissociation is the willingness to kill others for the simple reason that they are members of a hostile group."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Two groups will find themselves in a situation of mutual enmity if and only if there is a possibility of war and mutual killing between them. The distinction between friend and enemy thus refers to the 'utmost degree of intensity of an association or dissociation.'"

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The distinction between friend and enemy is essentially public and not private. Individuals may have personal enemies, but personal enmity is not a political phenomenon. Politics involves groups that face off as mutual enemies."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The specific political distinction is that between Friend and Enemy."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: Hatred of the Good for Being the Good: https://t.co/8OI0909Klv

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: The Law of Jante: https://t.co/RNO4hZxhcV

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: Tall Poppy Syndrome: https://t.co/DPY2UjAdu6

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: https://t.co/D1E4Rxi86T

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "...They desire nothing, they hate existence, and they keep running, each trying not to learn that the object of his hatred is himself."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "They do not want to own your fortune, they want you to lose it; they do not want to succeed, they want you to fail; they do not want to live, they want you to die..."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "In the most profound sense of the term, such a creature is a killer, not a physical, but a metaphysical one—it is not an enemy of your values, but of all values, it is an enemy of anything that enables men to survive, it is an enemy of life as such and of everything living."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "But consider the abstraction 'value,' apart from the particular content of any given code, and ask yourself: What is the nature of a creature in which the sight of a value arouses hatred and the desire to destroy?"

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The emotional mechanism is not set in reverse, but is set one way: its exponents do not experience love for evil men; their emotional range is limited to hatred or indifference. It is impossible to experience love when one’s automatized response to values is hatred."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The nature of the particular values a man chooses to hold is not the primary factor in this issue. The primary factor and distinguishing characteristic is an emotional mechanism set in reverse: a response of hatred, not toward human vices, but toward human virtues."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "If a man regards intelligence as a value, but is troubled by self-doubt and begins to hate the men he judges to be intelligent, that is hatred of the good."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "If a child wants to get good grades in school, but is unable or unwilling to achieve them and begins to hate the children who do, that is hatred of the good."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "This hatred is not resentment against some view of the good with which one does not agree. Hatred of the good for being the good means hatred of that which one regards as good by one’s own judgment. It means hatred of a person for possessing a value one regards as desirable."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Envy is regarded by most people as a petty, superficial emotion and, therefore, it serves as a semihuman cover for so inhuman an emotion that those who feel it seldom dare admit it even to themselves. That emotion is: Hatred of the good for being the good."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: https://t.co/5r8gwnQI2l

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "However, in Scandinavia, there have also been journalistic articles which link the Law of Jante to high suicide rates."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "While the original intention was as satire, Kim Orlin Kantardjiev claims that the Law of Jante is taught in schools as more of a social code to encourage group behavior, and wants to credit it with fueling Nordic countries' high happiness scores."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Although intended as criticism of society in general, the meaning of the Law of Jante has shifted to refer to personal criticism of people who want to break out of their social groups and reach a higher position."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Sandemose made no claim to having invented the rules; he simply sought to formulate social norms that had stamped the Danish and Norwegian psyches for centuries."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "An 11th rule recognized in the novel as 'the penal code of Jante' is: Perhaps you don't think we know a few things about you?"

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
8. You're not to laugh at us.
9. You're not to think anyone cares about you.
10. You're not to think you can teach us anything.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
4. You're not to imagine yourself better than we are.
5. You're not to think you know more than we do.
6. You're not to think you are more important than we are.
7. You're not to think you are good at anything.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:
1. You're not to think you are anything special.
2. You're not to think you are as good as we are.
3. You're not to think you are smarter than we are.

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "There are ten rules in the Law of Jante as defined by Sandemose, all expressive of variations on a single theme and usually referred to as a homogeneous unit: You are not to think you're anyone special, or that you're better than us."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Law of Jante is used generally in colloquial speech in the Nordic countries as a sociological term to denote a social attitude of disapproval towards expressions of individuality and personal success."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Law of Jante characterizes as unworthy and inappropriate any behavior that is not conforming, does things out of the ordinary, or is personally ambitious."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Law of Jante is a code of conduct created in fiction by the Danish-Norwegian author Aksel Sandemose and [is used] to explain the egalitarian nature of Nordic countries."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: https://t.co/BvrzocD8Es

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet:

https://t.co/TaYwgTVYS7

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The analogy in human behavior is that members of a group will attempt to reduce the self-confidence of any member who achieves success beyond the others, out of envy, resentment, spite, conspiracy, or competitive feelings, to halt their progress."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "As such, the crab mentality shares some features in common with a similar phenomenon of human behaviour called Tall Poppy Syndrome."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The metaphor is derived from a pattern of behavior noted in crabs when they are trapped in a bucket. While any one crab could easily escape, its efforts will be undermined by others, ensuring the group's collective demise."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Crab mentality, also known as crab theory, crabs in a bucket mentality, or the crab-bucket effect, is a way of thinking best described by the phrase 'If I can't have it, neither can you.'"

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "In cultural anthropology, a Leveling Mechanism is a practice that acts to ensure social equality, usually by shaming or humbling members of a group that attempt to put themselves above other members."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Since subordinates often mimic their leader, these associates do the same with those below them in the hierarchy, and the hierarchy becomes progressively filled over time with more and more incompetent people."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The person on the top of the hierarchy, wishing to remain in power forever, chooses his associates with the prime criterion of incompetence – they must not be competent enough to remove him from power."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Negative selection is a political process that occurs especially in rigid hierarchies, most notably dictatorships, but also to lesser degrees in such settings as corporations or electoral politics."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The messenger, tired of waiting for an answer, returned to Gabii and told Sextus what he had seen. Sextus realised that his father wished him to put to death all of the most eminent people of Gabii, which he then did."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Rather than answering the messenger verbally, Tarquin went into his garden, took a stick, and symbolically swept it across his garden, thus cutting off the heads of the tallest poppies that were growing there."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The specific reference to poppies occurs in Livy's account of the tyrannical Roman king, Lucius Tarquinius Superbus. He is said to have received a messenger from his son Sextus Tarquinius asking what he should do next in Gabii, since he had become all-powerful there."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "In Australia and New Zealand, 'cutting down the tall poppy' is used to describe those who deliberately put down another for their success and achievements. In Japan, a similar common expression is 'the nail that sticks up gets hammered down'."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Tall Poppy Syndrome is a cultural phenomenon in which people hold back, criticise, or sabotage those who have or are believed to have achieved notable success in one or more aspects of life."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: @NSmolenski @TuurDemeester You probably know the underlying theory? Rule by one (monarchy/tyranny), rule of the few (aristocracy/oligarchy), or rule of the many (democracy, which Michels says is impossible, or anarchy). Pick one. 🙂

tweet: The Tyranny of Structurelessness: https://t.co/R1cVYy1TRp

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: https://t.co/48CqT1aPJw

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Thus, to maintain [the elite's] own power, it is easier to rationalize the exclusion of the members of the other informal structure by such means as 'red-baiting,' 'lesbian-baiting,' or 'straight-baiting.'"

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Many informal elites hide under the banner of 'anti-elitism' and 'structurelessness.' To effectively counter the competition from another informal structure, they would have to become 'public,' and this possibility is fraught with many dangerous implications..."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "When a group is involved in a task, people learn to get along with others as they are and to subsume personal dislikes for the sake of the larger goal. There are limits placed on the compulsion to remold every person in our image of what they should be."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Able people with time on their hands and a need to justify their coming together put their efforts into personal control, and spend their time criticizing the personalities of the other members in the group."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "When a group has no specific task, the people in it turn their energies to controlling others in the group. This is not done so much out of a malicious desire to manipulate others (though sometimes it is) as out of a lack of anything better to do with their talents."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Unstructured groups may be very effective in getting women to talk about their lives; they aren't very good for getting things done."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Informal structures have no obligation to be responsible to the group at large. Their power was not given to them; it cannot be taken away."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The informal structure of decision-making will be much like a sorority -- one in which people listen to others because they like them and not because they say significant things."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "When informal elites are combined with a myth of 'structurelessness', there can be no attempt to put limits on the use of power. It becomes capricious."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "One joins such an elite much the same way one pledges a sorority. If perceived as a potential addition, one is 'rushed' by the members of the informal structure and eventually either dropped or initiated."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The characteristics prerequisite for participating in the informal elites of the movement, and thus for exercising power, concern one's background, personality, or allocation of time. They do not include one's competence..."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Once one knows with whom it is important to check before a decision is made, and whose approval is the stamp of acceptance, one knows who is running things."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Because elites are informal does not mean they are invisible. At any small group meeting anyone with a sharp eye and an acute ear can tell who is influencing whom."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Much of the energy of past women's movements has been directed to having the structures of decision-making and the selection processes formalized so that the exclusion of women could be confronted directly."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The inevitably elitist and exclusive nature of informal communication networks of friends is neither a new phenomenon characteristic of the women's movement nor a phenomenon new to women."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "...It is the coincidence of these two phenomena which creates elites in any group and makes them so difficult to break."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "...They would probably maintain their friendship whether or not they were involved in political activities; they would probably be involved in political activities whether or not they maintained their friendships..."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Elites are not conspiracies. Seldom does a small group of people get together and deliberately try to take over a larger group for its own ends. Elites are nothing more, and nothing less, than groups of friends who also happen to participate in the same political activities..."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The most insidious elites are people not known to the larger public at all. Intelligent elitists are usually smart enough not to allow themselves to become well known; when they become known, they are watched, and the mask over their power is no longer firmly lodged."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "A person becomes an elitist by being part of, or advocating the rule by, such a small group, whether or not that individual is well known or not known at all."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Correctly, an elite refers to a small group of people who have power over a larger group of which they are part, usually without direct responsibility to that larger group, and often without their knowledge or consent."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "A Structured group always has formal structure, and may also have an informal, or covert, structure. It is this informal structure, particularly in Unstructured groups, which forms the basis for elites."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "'Structurelessness' is organizationally impossible. We cannot decide whether to have a structured or structureless group, only whether or not to have a formally structured one."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Those who do not know the rules and are not chosen for initiation must remain in confusion, or suffer from paranoid delusions that something is happening of which they are not quite aware."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "As long as the structure of the group is informal, the rules of how decisions are made are known only to a few and awareness of power is limited to those who know the rules."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Thus structurelessness becomes a way of masking power, and within the women's movement is usually most strongly advocated by those who are the most powerful."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "This hegemony can be so easily established because the idea of 'structurelessness' does not prevent the formation of informal structures, only formal ones."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "A laissez faire group is about as realistic as a laissez faire society; the idea becomes a smokescreen for the strong or the lucky to establish unquestioned hegemony over others."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "This means that to strive for a structureless group is as useful, and as deceptive, as to aim at an 'objective' news story, 'value-free' social science, or a 'free' economy."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The very fact that we are individuals, with different talents, predispositions, and backgrounds makes this inevitable. Only if we refused to relate or interact on any basis whatsoever could we approximate structurelessness -- and that is not the nature of a human group."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The structure may be flexible; it may vary over time; it may evenly or unevenly distribute tasks, power and resources over the members of the group. But it will be formed regardless of the abilities, personalities, or intentions of the people involved."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Contrary to what we would like to believe, there is no such thing as a structureless group. Any group of people of whatever nature that comes together for any length of time for any purpose will inevitably structure itself in some fashion."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "At this point they usually foundered because most groups were unwilling to change their structure when they changed their tasks. Women had thoroughly accepted the idea of 'structurelessness' without realizing the limitations of its uses."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The basic problems didn't appear until individual rap groups exhausted the virtues of consciousness-raising and decided they wanted to do something more specific."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "For the early development of the movement this did not much matter. It early defined its main goal, and its main method, as consciousness-raising, and the 'structureless' rap group was an excellent means to this end."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The idea of 'structurelessness,' however, has moved from a healthy counter to those tendencies to becoming a goddess in its own right."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The source of this idea was a natural reaction against the over-structured society in which most of us found ourselves, and the inevitable control this gave others over our lives, and the continual elitism among those who were supposedly fighting this overstructuredness."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "During the years in which the women's liberation movement has been taking shape, a great emphasis has been placed on what are called leaderless, structureless groups as the main -- if not sole -- organizational form of the movement."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The more unstructured a group is, the more lacking it is in structures, and the more it adheres to an ideology of 'Structurelessness,' the more vulnerable it is to being taken over by a [ruling class]."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: Vanguard: https://t.co/vCAsAsoejE

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Communist-inspired constitutions enshrined this by giving the Communist parties a 'leading role'—a provision that was interpreted to either ban other parties altogether or force them to accept the Communists' guaranteed right to rule as a condition of being allowed to exist."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The concept of a Vanguard was used by the Bolsheviks to justify their suppression of other parties. They took the line that since they were the vanguard of the proletariat, their right to rule could not be legitimately questioned."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "...On the other hand, theoretically, they have over the great mass of the proletariat the advantage of clearly understanding the lines of march, the conditions, and the ultimate general results of the proletarian movement."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Communists, therefore, are, on the one hand, practically the most advanced and resolute section of the working-class parties of every country, that section which pushes forward all others..."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Friedrich Engels and Karl Marx presented the concept of the Vanguard as solely qualified to politically lead the proletariat in revolution in The Communist Manifesto."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Lenin, the first leader of the Bolsheviks, coined the term 'vanguard party', and argued that such a party was necessary in order to provide the practical and political leadership that would impel the proletariat to achieve a communist revolution."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "In the praxis of political science, the concept of the Vanguard, composed of professional revolutionaries, was first effected by the Bolshevik Party in the Russian Revolution of 1917."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "In Lenin's view, after the revolution the working class would implement the dictatorship of the proletariat to rule the new worker's state. Here it can be said that the vanguard disappears, as all of society now consists of revolutionaries." 👀

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "This is, according to Leninists, a vital function as mass revolutions can sometimes be easily crushed by the disciplined military of the ruling classes. The Vanguard would serve as commanders of the revolt, chosen to their positions by 'democratic natural selection'."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Once the proletariat gained class consciousness and thus was prepared to revolt against the ruling classes, the Vanguard would serve another purpose. The Vanguard would coordinate the proletariat through its revolution by acting as a military command hub of sorts."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "[The Vanguard] would belong to the party cadres as professional revolutionaries, and would be elected to leadership positions by the mass party membership."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Vanguard would protect Marxism from outside corruption from other ideas as well as advance its concepts, and would educate the proletariat in order to cleanse them of their 'false individual consciousness' and instill the revolutionary 'class consciousness' in them."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Lenin argued that Marxism's complexity and the hostility of the establishment required a close-knit group of individuals pulled from the working class Vanguard to safeguard the revolutionary ideology."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Vanguard [consists of] the most class-conscious and politically 'advanced' sections of the proletariat; forms organizations to draw the working class to revolutionary politics and serves as manifestations of proletarian political power opposed to the [status quo]."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: https://t.co/PDtxyW1v6V

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: Iron Law of Oligarchy: https://t.co/uVng3PGCUx

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Iron Law of Oligarchy states that organizations, regardless of how democratic they start, will eventually and inevitably develop oligarchic tendencies, thus making true democracy practically and theoretically impossible, especially in large groups and complex organizations."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Bureaucracy by design leads to centralization of power by the leaders. Leaders also have control over sanctions and rewards. They tend to promote those who share their opinions, which inevitably leads to self-perpetuating oligarchy."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Bureaucratization and specialization are the driving processes behind the Iron Law. They result in the rise of a group of professional administrators in a hierarchical organization, which in turn leads to the rationalization and routinization of authority and decision-making."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Michels also argued that for leaders in organizations, 'The desire to dominate is universal. These are elementary psychological facts.' Thus, they are prone to seek power and dominance."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Delegation leads to specialization—to the development of knowledge bases, skills and resources among a leadership—which further alienates the leadership from the rank and file and entrenches the leadership in office."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "...For the organization to function effectively, centralization has to occur and power will end up in the hands of a few. Those few—the oligarchy—will use all means necessary to preserve and further increase their power."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Any large organization has to create a bureaucracy in order to maintain its efficiency as it becomes larger—many decisions have to be made daily that cannot be made by large numbers of disorganized people..."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Darcy K. Leach summarized the factors underlying the Iron Law of Oligarchy briefly as: 'Bureaucracy happens. If bureaucracy happens, power rises. Power corrupts.'"

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The more liberal and democratic modern era allowed the formation of organizations with innovative and revolutionary goals, but as such organizations became more complex, they became less and less democratic and revolutionary."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "In 1911 Robert Michels argued that paradoxically the socialist parties of Europe, despite their democratic ideology, were dominated by their leaders just like traditional conservative parties. Michels' conclusion was that the problem lay in the very nature of organizations."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The official goal of representative democracy of eliminating elite rule is impossible, representative democracy is a façade legitimizing the rule of a particular elite, and that elite rule--oligarchy--is inevitable."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Democratic attempts to hold leadership positions accountable are prone to fail, since with power comes the ability to reward loyalty, to control information about the organization, and to control what procedures the organization follows when making decisions."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "By controlling who has access to information, those in power can centralize their power, often with little accountability, due to the apathy, indifference and non-participation most rank-and-file members have in relation to their organization's decision-making processes."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Far from being 'servants of the masses', this 'leadership class', rather than the organization's membership, will inevitably grow to dominate the organization's power structures."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "All organizations eventually come to be run by a 'leadership class', who often function as paid administrators, executives, spokespersons or political strategists for the organization."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Robert Michels addressed the application of this law to representative democracy, and stated: 'Who says organization, says oligarchy.' He went on to state that 'Historical evolution mocks all the prophylactic measures that have been adopted for the prevention of oligarchy.'"

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "All complex organizations, regardless of how democratic they start, develop into oligarchies. No large and complex organization can function purely as a direct democracy; power within an organization will always get delegated to individuals within that group, elected or not."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Iron Law of Oligarchy asserts that rule by an elite, or oligarchy, is inevitable as an 'iron law' within any democratic organization as part of the 'tactical and technical necessities' of the organization."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "[The Eastern Bloc] form of bureaucratic collectivism is supposed to integrate various sectors of society, such as labor unions, corporations, and government organizations, in order to keep contradictions in the economy from developing into a general meltdown."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Oligarchical collectivism was Orwell's fictionalized conceptualization of bureaucratic collectivism, where Big Brother and the Inner Party form the nucleus of a hierarchical organization of society, only concerned with total domination by the Party."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "It is the bureaucracy—not the workers, or the people in general—which controls the economy and the state. Thus, the system is not truly socialist, but it is not capitalist either."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "A bureaucratic collectivist state owns the means of production, while the surplus or profit is distributed among an elite party bureaucracy (Nomenklatura), rather than among the working class."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Finally, Đilas predicted a period of economic decline, as the political future of the new class was consolidated around a staid programme of corruption and self-interest at the expense of other social classes."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "After security has been achieved, the new class pursues a policy of moderation towards its own members, effectively granting material rewards and freedom of thought and action within the new class, so long as this freedom is not used to undermine the rule of the new class."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "As the new class suborns all other interests to its own security, it freely executes and purges its own members in order to achieve its major goal of security as a ruling class."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Đilas used this argument about property forms to indicate why the new class sought parades, marches and spectacles despite this activity lowering the levels of material productivity."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "For Đilas, the new class not only seeks expanded material reproduction to politically justify its existence to the working class but also seeks expanded reproduction of political control as a form of property in itself."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Đilas posited that the new class' specific relationship to the means of production was one of collective political control, and that the new class' property form was political control."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "It was Đilas' observation as a member of a Communist government that Party members stepped into the role of ruling class, a problem which he believed should be corrected through revolution [which would have, of course, resulted in the creation of yet another new class...]."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The theory of the new class can be considered to oppose the theories of certain ruling Communists, such as Joseph Stalin, who argued that their revolutions and/or social reforms would result in the extinction of any ruling class as such."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "'New class' is used as a term by critics of countries that followed the Soviet-type Communism to describe the privileged ruling class of bureaucrats and Communist party functionaries which arose in these states."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Milovan Đilas, a critic of Stalin, called the Nomenklatura the 'new class', and he claimed that it was seen by ordinary citizens as a bureaucratic elite that enjoyed special privileges and had supplanted the earlier wealthy capitalist élites."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Promotion in the bureaucratic-political hierarchy was the only path to power. The most important criterion for promotion in this hierarchy was approval from one's supervisors, who evaluated their subordinates on the basis of political criteria."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "All of the 2 million members of the Nomenklatura system understood that they held their positions only as a result of a favor bestowed on them by a superior official in the party and that they could easily be replaced if they manifested disloyalty to their patron."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Nomenklatura system arose early in Soviet history. Vladimir Lenin wrote that appointments were to take the following criteria into account: reliability, political attitude, qualifications, and administrative ability."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Soviet power structure essentially consisted of groups of vassals (clients) who had an overlord (the patron). The higher the patron, the more clients the patron had. By promoting his clients' careers, the patron could advance his own power."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The patron promoted the interests of clients in return for their support. Powerful patrons, such as the members of the Politburo, had many clients. An official could be both a client (in relation to a higher-level patron) and a patron (to other, lower-level officials)."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Coextensive with the Nomenklatura were patron-client relations. Officials who had the authority to appoint individuals to certain positions cultivated loyalties among those whom they appointed."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "The Nomenklatura referred to the Communist Party's power to make appointments to key positions throughout the governmental system, as well as throughout the Party's own hierarchy."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Virtually all members of the Nomenklatura were members of the Communist Party. Richard Pipes said that the Nomenklatura system mainly reflected a continuation of the old Tsarist regime, as many former Tsarist officials or 'careerists' joined the Bolshevik government."

name: Marc Andreessen
tweet: "Nomenklatura were people within the Soviet Union who held various key administrative positions in the bureaucracy, running all spheres of those countries' activity: government, industry, agriculture, education, etc., whose positions were granted only with approval by the Party."
